Explanation: Explanation: A beam is a horizontal structural member subjected to transverse load perpendicular to its own axis. Beams are used to support weights of roof slabs, walls and staircases.  The type of beam usually depends upon the span, type of load elasticity and type of structure.

Question: 2. Example for cantilever beam is ______
Explanation: Explanation: A beam which is fixed at one end and is free at other end, it is called cantilever beam. The examples for it are portico slabs and sunshades.

Question: 4. Fixed beam is also known as __________
Explanation: Explanation: A beam which is fixed at both supports is called fixed beam or encastered beam. All framed structures are examples of fixed beams.

Question: 5. U.D.L stands for?
Explanation: Explanation: These loads are uniformly spread over a portion or whole area. They are generally represented as rate of load that is Kilo Newton per meter length (KN/m).

Question: 7. Moving train is an example of ____ load.
Explanation: Explanation: As trainÕs wheels (rolling stock) move in rolling way.The upcoming load will be considered as rolling load.

Question: 8. Continuous beams are _________
Explanation: Explanation: Fixed beams and continuous beams are statically indeterminate beams which cannot be analyzed only by using static equations.

Question: 9. A beam which extends beyond it supports can be termed as __________
Explanation: Explanation: A Beam extended beyond its support. And the position of extension is called as over hung portion.

Question: 10. Units of U.D.L?
Explanation: Explanation: As these loads distribute over span the units for this kind of loads will be load per meter length i.e KN/m. It is denoted by ÒwÓ.

Explanation: Explanation: The shear force at the cross section of a beam may also be defined as the unbalanced vertical force to the left or right of section. It is also the algebraic sum of all the forces I get to the left to the right of the section.

Question: 2. SI units of shear force is __
Explanation: Explanation: As shear force at any section is equal to the algebraic sum of the forces, the units of the shear force is also in kilo newtons and it is denoted by kN.

Question: 4. Shear force is diagram is _______representation of shear force plotted as ordinate.
Explanation: Explanation:  Shear Force diagram is a graphical representation of the shear force plotted as ordinate on baseline representing the axis of the Beam.

Question: 5. Hogging is________
Explanation: Explanation: The bending moment at a section is considered to be negative when it causes convexity upwards or concavity at bottom, such bending moment is called hogging bending moment or negative bending moment.

Question: 6. At the point of contraflexure, the value of bending moment is____
Explanation: Explanation:  A point at which bending moment changes its sign from positive to negative and vice versa. Such point is termed as point of contraflexure.  At this point, the value of bending moment is zero (0).

Question: 7. _________ positive/negative bending moments occur where shear force changes its sign.
Explanation: Explanation:  If shear force and bending moment values obtained are thus plotted as diagram, the SF & BM relationship always behaves vice versa.

Question: 9. SI units of Bending moment is ____
Explanation: Explanation: Moment is product of force and perpendicular distance and the bending moment is the algebraic sum of moments taken away from the left or the right of the section hence the SI units of bending moment is same as the moment i.e kNm.

Question: 10. What is the other name for positive bending moment?
Explanation: Explanation: The bending moment at a section is considered to be positive when it causes convexity downwards such bending moment is called sagging bending moment positive bending moment.

Question: 1. A simple support offers only_______ reaction normal to the axis of the beam.
Explanation: Explanation: In a simple support there will not be any resistance to horizontal loads, moment or rotation.In fact, it only offers vertical reaction normal to the axis of the beam.

Question: 2. To avoid _____ stresses in beams, one end of beam is placed on the rollers.
Explanation: Explanation: Roller support reaction is normal to the axis of the beam. In case the beam subjected   to trust or to avoid temperature stresses in the beam, one end of the beam is placed on roller,   because it facilitate free horizontal movement of end. It is similar to simple support.

Question: 3. ________support develops support moment.
Explanation: Explanation: A fixed support offers resistance against horizontal and vertical movement and against rotation of the member and that in turn developers support moment.

Question: 4. Hinge support is called as ____
Explanation: Explanation: Hinge support is one, in which the position is fixed but not the direction.In ther words hinged support offers resistance against vertical and horizontal moments.it is fixed in such a way that it resembles like a pin joint.

Question: 6. For a simply supported beam, the moment at the support is always____
Explanation: Explanation: As the moment is a product of force and perpendicular distance, the flexural moment at the support is zero because there is no distance at the support.

Question: 9. Roller support is same as _____
Explanation: Explanation: The support reaction is normal to the axis of beam. It facilitates the vertical support. It helps the beam to overcome the temperature stresses effectively. It is similar to simple support.

Question: 10. Hinged supports offers vertical and ________ reaction.
Explanation: Explanation: A hinged support offers a vertical and horizontal reaction. The pin jointed support offers resistance against horizontal and vertical movements but not against rotation movement.

Explanation: Explanation: Point of contraflexure in a beam is a point at which bending moment changes its sign from positive to negative and vice versa. Point of inflection is popularly known as point of contraflexure. At the point of contraflexure, the value of bending moment is zero.

Explanation: Explanation: The line to which the longitudinal axis of a beam bends or deflects or deviates under given load is known as elastic curve on deflection curve. Elastic curve can also be known as elastic line or elastic axis.

Explanation: Explanation: The relationship between slope and maximum bending moment is inversely proportional because, For example in simply supported beams slope is maximum at supports and zero at midspan of a symmetrically loaded beam where as bending moment is zero at supports and maximum at mid span. Question: 1. In simple bending, ______ is constant.
Explanation: Explanation: If a beam is undergone with simple bending, the beam deforms under the action of bending moment.  If this bending moment is constant and does not affected by any shear force, then the beam is in state of simple bending.

Question: 2. If a beam is subjected to pure bending, then the deformation of beam is_____
Explanation: Explanation: The beam being subjected to pure bending, there will be only bending moment and no shear force it results in the formation of an arc of circle with some radius known as radius of curvature.

Question: 3. When a beam is subjected to simple bending, ____________ is same in both tension and compression for the material.
Explanation: Explanation: It is one of the most important assumptions made in the theory of simple bending that is the modulus of elasticity that is YoungÕs modulus [E]  is same in both tension and compression for the material and the stress in a beam do not exceed the elastic limit.

Question: 5. Maximum Shearing stress in a beam is at _____
Explanation: Explanation: Shearing stress is defined as the resistance offered by the internal stress to the shear force. Shearing stress in a beam is maximum at neutral axis.

Question: 6. At the neutral axis, bending stress is _____
Explanation: Explanation: Neutral axis is defined as a line of intersection of neutral plane or neutral layer on a cross section at the neutral axis of that section.  At the NA, bending stress or bending strain is zero. The first moment of area of a beam section about neutral axis is also zero. The layer of neutral axis neither contracts nor extends.

Explanation: Explanation: The product of youngÕs modulus (E) of the material and moment of inertia (I) of the beam section about its neutral axis is called flexural rigidity.Units for E are N/m2Units for I are m4Their product is Nm2.

Explanation: Explanation: Axial rigidity is a product of youngÕs modulus (E) and the cross-sectional area (A) of that section. Axial rigidity per unit length is known as axial stiffness the s i units of axial stiffness are Newton per metre (N/m).
